text: A young man is walking along the tracks. A slow, aimless walk. Lost and lonely. A setting sun at his back. He's handsome in a rugged, dangerous way. Denim and leather. A great sadness and confusion on his face. His name is KEITH NELSON. DRUMS OBLITERATE THE STRINGS, and we RETURN TO BLACK and TITLES BEGIN.

She's playing drums to the TRACK. Hard, serious. With great purpose and need. She's boyish and tough. Her prettiness is intentionally buried beneath acres of atti- tude. This is WATTS. DRUMMER GIRL. FADE TO BLACK.
Beautiful girl, handsome boy. Perfection meets perfection Making-out against the yellow slatted light of a darkened bedroom. She's AMANDA JONES. He's HARDY JENNS. FADE TO BLACK.
A freight train is thundering down the tracks. A HORN BLA The speeding bulk dominates the FRAME. The SOUND of DIESE ENGINES and CHATTERING TRACK obliterates the MUSIC.
The boy we saw before, Keith Nelson, continues down the t He looks up. (CONTINUED)
The train is bearing down on him.
BEHIND Keith TO SEE that he's walking into the approachin train. The HORN BLASTS AGAIN.
Watching the train. No reaction. A collision with the tra will only give him what he wants. Change.
The train shudders and rocks on the track. The HORN BLAST AND HOLDS.
Still no change in expression.
FROM BEHIND Keith. The train FILLS THE FRAME. It's nearly on him. He steps out off the tracks at the last moment.
Keith heads down the embankment as the train hurtles past No change in expression.

The homes of working people. Squat bungalows, clean but modest. A black Corvette is parked in the driveway of one of the houses. It stands out among the more utilitarian vehicles on the street. An incongruent luxury. A front door opens, and the boy and the girl we saw making-out in the TITLE SEQUENCE step out of the house. Her blouse is untucked, her hair's mussed, stocking feet. She's flushed and floating. He's in a hurry. Done with her, on to other things. She holds him back and kisses him. There's no tenderness on his part. It's one-sided.

Keith is across the street, leaning on a lamp post. His gritty hands wrapped around the pole. Washed but never clean. A hint of anger, a touch of resentment. Hardy doesn't belong in the neighborhood. Certainly doesn't de- serve the girl. (CONTINUED)

Hardy gets in his car, fires the engine and backs out of the driveway. Amanda waves goodbye from the porch. Hardy drops the Corvette in gear and squeals away. An irresis- table show of disrespect for the neighborhood.
There's something tragic about his look. Hardy has every- thing money can buy and is now stealing the things it can
Amanda goes back in the house.
His observation was careful and considered. He looks at his greasy hands. Too dirty to touch her. He pushes off the pole.

A tired two story in a modest neighborhood. Clean but sim Maybe a little nicer than Amanda's neighborhood. But not much. Keith cuts across the freshly mown lawn, up the dri way and around the back of the house.

Keith's mother, CAROL, is at a small built-in desk beneat a wall phone balancing her checkbook. She's wearing nurse whites. She works. Dinner is on the fire. A ten-year-old girl, CINDY, is sitting at the kitchen table. She's cata- loguing her Garbage Pail kids in a photo album. Keith com in the back door. Cindy strikes.
It's Semi-Conscious Keith. Keith ignores her and continues through the kitchen. Caro addresses him without looking up.
Hi, honey. How was work? He exits into the dining room.
You still haven't told me when you're going to cut your hair. (CONTINUED)
Mom? You're flapping your lips in vain. Keith vacated. Carol addresses Cindy without looking up.
Speak English, please.
Keith crosses out of the dining into the foyer. His fathe calls to him from the living room.
Keith? Is that you? Keith stops at the bottom of the stairs. He sighs. Caught He swings around and steps into the living room.
Keith's father, CLIFF, is sitting on the couch. Spread ou before him are university brochures.
He looks at Cliff and the brochures. He's suspicious.
He speaks without looking at Keith.
I've been checking out colleges... He looks up at Keith.
Plays it flat.
Aren't you a little too old for college? A thin smile breaks through.
An incredulous stare. Incredulous that Keith can be so cavalier about a subject that Cliff considers vital, pres ing and overwhelmingly serious. There's no humor to his retort. (CONTINUED)
If I'd gone to college, I wouldn't be selling tires six days a week.
He doesn't like hearing Cliff run himself down.
A word of warning.

If you don't get with the program, you'll be selling tires, too. (pause; lightens- up) You want to take a minute and look at these brochures? A whole bunch of new ones came in the mail today. (sorts through stack, finds one, holds it up) Take a look. Some of these are real nice. Look at this, coed physical education.
The last thing he wants to do.
Can I do it later?
He's been put off before.
I'm not trying to break your back, I just want you to get off the dime and think about your future.
He nods. He's heard it before.
One last thought. What's really at the heart of the colle issue. (CONTINUED)
You got a shot to be the first guy in this family who didn't have to wash his hands after a day's work.

He knows. All too well. He shows his hands to Cliff. Dirty. Motor dirt. Like Cliff said. He pushes off the door arch and heads back into the foyer. He heads up the stairs, side-stepping the debris piled on the stairs to be carried up at anyone's convenience.
Keith opens the door and stops cold.

Keith's sister, LAURA, is sitting on the floor going thro his records. LP's are out of their sleeves. She's rudely holding an LP, looking at the label. Keith's room is a shrine to art. It's a serious shelter from the outside world. One wall is covered, every inch, with reproduction posters, art show posters, art postcard reproductions torn from books and magazines. A collage of the history of art. A second wall is devoted to his own sketches. A third wall is a trompe l'oeil of an endless marble gallery. The fourth wall is hung with his own can- vases. A stereo carefully put together out of discarded pieces and parts. His bed is a mattress on the floor. A chair direct from the dump. A rug from off a curb during spring trash pick-up day. A desk made of an old door held up by two oil drums. The surface is covered with sketches and india ink pens and brushes, ink bottles. Clay and pla ter models and studies. Everywhere are found objects, things intended for future pieces and studies. It is an artist's studio in a boy's bedroom. There's no question from his surroundings that he's serious about his talent.
I'm looking for that song about the guy that killed himself for the girl that hated his guts. She looks up.
He's furious at the intrusion. (CONTINUED)
Disregards his anger.
Do you know which song I'm talking about? Keith takes the LP from Laura.
Do you understand the concept of privacy?
Yes, I do. That's why I don't let anyone in my room.
Get out of here before I throw your ass out the window.
(outraged) God, are you in a bad mood!
Get outta here.
Is this a side effect of being massively unliked or...? Keith grabs Laura by the arm, rips her to her feet, walks her to the door and shoves her out.
She's enraged.
If I get a black and blue mark you monger, you're dead! The door slams on her. She screams at the top of her voic
Mom!
The family are eating dinner. Laura is showing her upper arm to Carol.
Look at it. You see what he did to me? Carol looks.
I don't see anything.
Then you need glasses. If I wanted to sit out, I couldn't wear a bathing suit.
Exposing your skin to sunlight will make you old before your time.
(to Laura) You stay out of his room. (to Keith) You got a problem with her, see me before you rough her up.
What right does she have to break into my room? And I didn't rough her up.
I have practically no feeling left in the upper part of my arm.
Drop it.
I wish just once you guys could experience the humiliation of having the weirdest guy ina huge school be a blood relative.
Your father said, drop it.
This whole family revolves around Keith. I'm sick of it. (CONTINUED)
Keith sets down his fork and napkin.
That's not true and you know it.
(to Carol) I'll be upstairs.
You haven't finished your dinner.
Excuse me. Keith gets up and exists. Cliff calls after him.
What about these colleges, Keith? (pause) I expect an answer.

Do you know what a total waste of money it's going to be letting him go to college? He'll have this expensive education that he'll never use because all he wants to do is make incredibly ugly art that won't ever look good in anybody's house. Cliff, Carol and Cindy stare at her.
Am I wrong?
MUSIC'S PLAYING. He's sitting at his desk looking at a tattered photo.
A candid snapshot. Of a girl looking back over her shoul- der. A caught expression on her face. A beautiful girl. The girl we saw in the opening.
Dips his brush in ink and applies it to paper. (CONTINUED)
A steady hand draws the sweep of a girl's neck and shoul- der. Another produces a fine, strong jawline.
A hint of a smile as he looks at his first strokes. The SOURCE MUSIC PLAYING in the room is lost to a DRUM TRACK PLAYED AS SCORE. The DRUMS CONTINUE ACROSS the:
A big, traditional high school.

A battered, wasted Mini with English drive whips into the parking lot and flies into a parking spot narrowly missin the shiny new imports on either side of the vacant spot. DRUMS OUT ON A CYMBAL SPLASH.

The car door opens and a black patent-leather tie shoe, covered with metal studs steps out of the car. We MOVE UP FROM the shoes, PAST worn, torn jeans, a tank top, black man's brocade vest, drum sticks shoved in a black leather belt, red kid gloves and a cheap digital watch on a metal stretch band shoved halfway up the arm to the girl we saw in the opening. She's Watts, Drummer Girl. Big breathless smile enjoying the rush of a near miss, the affirmation o life that comes from a challenge to it. She takes off her tiny red sunglasses and looks in the car.
Are you aware of how close that was?
Keith looks up at her. He's annoyed with her driving. The answer to her question is on his face. He can't help but smile at her exhilaration. He picks up his books off the seat and gets out.
Keith gets out of the car. He has to squeeze out. Drummer Girl's parked a bit close on his side. (CONTINUED)
Imagine what I can do when I get my driver's license back. She gives him a big smile and twirls her drumsticks.

Hardy Jenns and a couple of his friends are hanging in th parking lot. Leaning against a tricked-out Toyota truck. MUSIC's coming from inside the truck. Hardy's bending the radio antenna over. With his free hand, he's holding the owner of the car away. His intention isn't to do damage, only to harass his friend. The game is interrupted as something catches Hardy's eye.
Drummer Girl and Keith heading into school.
Hardy lets the antenna go. He points out Keith and Drumme Girl. Big derisive smiles.
Drummer Girl and Keith head across the lot to the school. They're unaware that they're being observed. She's fiddl- ing with her drumsticks as she walks.
You don't have any books?
Not on me.
You never study, do you?
Not school stuff. My urge is to make music. Tell me how reading "Lord Of The Flies' '1l make me a better drummer.
You have no desire to get out of this place?
You're talking to someone who was raised on cocktail onions and cigarette butts. (MORE)
I'd like nothing better. I have two feet. I'll get out. I'm not worried. You must be getting heat from the old man about college again.
It's all he thinks about.
In comparative terms, it's probably better to have an old man nagging you about the future than to have no old man not nagging you about anything.
Things not too great at home?
The same. The reach for the school doors. There's a crowd. Drummer Girl taps out a little riff on the back pack of a kid standing in front of her.
It doesn't matter. As long as you stand by me, I'm covered.
Where would I be without you?

Seeing as how I drive you to school every day, you'd probably be sitting on your front porch. The kid Drummer Girl is tapping on turns around. He's an angry little freshman dead head. His name is Ray.
Do you mind?
Very much so. Drummer Girl twirls her stick and gives the kid a pop on the top of his head. She steps in front of him and opens the door for Keith.  27 28 13.

Keith and Drummer Girl continue down a crowded hallway. It's a corridor claimed by the headbangers. The angry flotsam of the school loiters on the window ledges, lis- tening to MUSIC, laying comatose, talking loudly, verball abusing anyone and everyone that passes. Including Keith. His dark clothes, blank expression and boots make him ap- pear at home in the corridor. But he's not immune to at- tack.
Hey! Paint my picture!
(to Keith) Some day when your shit's hanging in a museum and these guys are OD'd you'll be laughing.
I'm laughing now.
I think it's hip that you paint. I think it's hip that I drum. And it's perfect that we're friends. Keith stops. Drummer Girl stops. He looks down.
A leg is stuck out, across his path. We MOVE UP TO a big, ugly-looking SKINHEAD. He smiles.
He stares at the kid. Doesn't give up anything.
Keith steps over the obstruction. The Skinhead pulls his leg in as Keith raises his leg and makes him highstep ove nothing. A laugh. Keith stares at the Skinhead.
That's real original. How long you been pulling that one?
(unfazed) How long have you been a lesbian? Drummer Girl's face goes ashen. Keith's face tightens. (CONTINUED)

You're carrying too much up front to be a guy. So you must be a... Keith grabs Skinhead by his jacket front and pulls him to his feet. He realizes that he's grabbed more than he anticipated. Skinhead towers over him.
A MALE TEACHER rudely shoves his way through the crowd. He's assigned the security. Shirt-sleeves and tie and two way radio on his belt.
That's enough! He grabs Keith's shoulder and pushes him aside.
Clear out! Keith backs away.
Now! He turns and heads down the hall. Drummer Girl points her drumstick at Skinhead.
Wimp. She follows after Keith. The teacher turns to Skinhead.
I didn't do anything! He jumped on me! Why don't you nail him? The teacher flips a pack of Marlboro's out of Skinhead's shirt pocket.
It's not my shirt. He reaches around behind and yanks a half pint out of his hip pocket.
That's just for show. He reaches in the other pocket and takes out a packet of scene playing cards. The teacher looks at them. (CONTINUED)
Those were a gift. He tries his most charming smile.
You just got detention, mister.
Keith's slumped down in a chair in the back of the librar He's working in a sketchpad. He's got his eye on somethin Drawing.
The girl we saw in the opening and in the photograph, Ama Jones, is across the room and forward of Keith. A boy is sitting at her table. His back is to Keith.
He's obviously very taken with her. Watching her every move. He feels eyes upon him. An uneasiness comes over him. His eyes shift quickly.
Hardy's turned in his seat, looking directly at Keith. He's not pleased.
He's caught. He looks down to avoid the stare. A beat and he looks up.
We see that Hardy was the boy with his back to Keith. He's turned around in his seat. Amanda looks from Hardy to Keith.
Tries to convince himself that he's not intimidated. Look away. Another beat and he returns his look to Hardy.
He's still staring at Keith. He points to Keith, holds up a pencil, points to Amanda, points to his neck, points to Keith, points to the pencil, turns it straight up and sna it in half. (CONTINUED)
A crusty, older woman looks up with a scowl and lets out a loud, shhh!
Looks at Hardy to let him know that he doesn't scare that easily.
She looks from Hardy to Keith. Wondering what Keith is doing.
Keith is walking down the hallway. Drummer Girl pushes her way through the crowd to Keith.
Keith! He stops. She's flustered and nervous.
Are you sitting down?
No. I'm standing in the hall.
Right. I have some bad news.
What?
This is unconfirmed but I have it from a reliable source.
What?
I think your father's at school.
How do you know it's my father?
You know those hats he wears?
A straw panama is resting on a desk.
Cliff has taken half an hour off work to visit Keith's counselor, a gaunt man in his fifties, MR. GALE.
So there's nothing special we need to know about filling out the applications?
Just what we've covered.
I don't mean to be a pain in the butt about this, I just want to double-check. You know kids they wait until the last minute on everything.
You have plenty of time. Has Keith decided on a school yet?
We're zeroing in on a few.
He's indicated to me an interest in a couple of art schools.
I don't think that's going to happen. He comes out of an art school, what's he qualified to do? I'm looking for a good business program. I think he has a good head for business.
The indications I've gotten are that he's more creatively inclined.
Fine. We're looking for a business school. He can be creative in his spare time. How's he doing other- wise?
Fine. (CONTINUED)
SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 18.
Grades holding up?
Very well. Cliff picks up his hat and offers his hand to Mr. Gale.
Good. Thanks for the time.
If you have any more questions don't hesitate to call.
I appreciate it.

Cliff heads down an empty hallway. We MOVE AHEAD OF him TO Skinhead. He's standing at a locker, prying it open with a large screwdriver. He hears Cliff coming, turns TOWARD CAMERA, shoves the screwdriver down his front and closes his jacket. To avoid a problem, Skinhead takes the immediate offensive position. He turns as Cliff reaches him.
Excuse me, sir. Can I see your hall pass? Cliff is surprised by the request.
I don't have a pass. I'ma parent. I was seeing Mr. Gale. I'm on my way out.

Please don't think me rude, sir, but we have to limit access to these hallways to students and authorized persons only. You have no idea how many unsavory types try to gain entry to the school to prey on the youngsters. They bring in contraband, controlled substances, obscene rock 'n roll lyrics. I'm telling you, sir, it's like wolves running free in the hen house. (CONTINUED)
SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 18A.
I'm heading right out.
I'm sure you are, sir. You have an honest face and an overall honorable body shape. I'm just alerting you to the rules. From a concerned teen to a concerned parent.
Boy, I got two kids who I wished had your attitude.
It's refreshing, isn't it?
Very. Thanks.
God bless. Cliff smiles and continues on his way. Skinhead waits a beat and returns to the locker.
She's sitting in class. All eyes turn to the door.
He waves to Laura.
We PUSH IN ON her face as she screams.

Keith's wearing paint-splattered jeans and a T-shirt. He's sitting on the back of a chair, studying a canvas he's working on. He's holding a paint brush in his teeth. It's after school. Late. He hears talking in the hallway. He looks out the door.
Hardy and a sophomore girl, MIA, are talking in the hall- way.
He studies the situation, listens carefully.  34 35 36 19.

Mia's back is to the lockers. Hardy's standing in front of her, leaning forward, resting his elbow on the locker. Engulfing her. She's completely under his spell. He's older, he's richer, he's handsome, he's popular, he's dangerous.
(softens) I want you to stay close but not too close. You back off when I say, okay? She nods, yes.
It'll get good. Mia nods. He gives her a gentle kiss.
Both your parents work? Mia nods.
Good. Maybe I'll come over after school one day this week.

Hardy and Mia. The tail end of the kiss. Hardy pulls back from her. He looks down the hall and catches Amanda looking at him. He steps back from Mia. She shoots a look to Amanda. Hardy looks at her. She heads off down the hall. Hardy smiles. He starts toward Amanda with his arms outspread.
(to himself) Shit...
She turns to her locker and opens it. She's angry and hurt. Hardy approaches her, acting as if he's done no- thing wrong.
You wanna go to your place? (CONTINUED)
Amanda glares at him, throws her books in her locker and grabs her coat.
What's wrong? Amanda tries to get away. Hardy blocks her.
Do you mind?
Yes I do. I want to know what's wrong. Amanda doesn't respond?
Mia?
I'm impressed, you asked her name.

She's a friend of my little sister. Her brother was ina pretty serious car accident, and she's a little upset. Amanda glares at him. She's never been very good holding up her side of an argument with Hardy.
I'm waiting for you. I know you're coming, why would I be trying to make another girl? It makes no sense at all. Amanda backs down a bit. He's charming logic leaves her without an immediate counter.
How can you be so beautiful and so insecure at the same time? In lieu of something to say, she holds her look on him.
Trust is the basis of any relationship. I trust you. He leans forward and kisses her forehead. (CONTINUED)
SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 21. 36 37 38 39 40 4l 42

I'll drive you home. He points to a ring on his baby finger. He points to her. He slips it off, takes her hand, slips the ring on her finger and kisses her again. She doesn't say yes. She doesn't say no. Hardy takes the answer as yes.

I'll get the car and meet you in front. He heads down the hall. In the direction Mia went. Amanda looks at the floor and sighs angrily. She's upset with herself. She wants to bust him but can't. She senses that she's being watched. She turns.
Keith's standing in an open doorway looking at her.
She feels uncomfortable. Wonders if he overheard the con- versation. She'd rather keep her acquiescence to Hardy a secret.
He's heard it all. He's worried for her. He knows what a stroke job she got. He gives her a two finger salute and a smile.
It's too close. She exits.
He watches the empty doorway for a long beat. He picks up his brush, dips it in a jar of turpentine and cleans it o his work shirt.
Keith's done for the day. He lays the brush down, peels off the shirt and looks at the canvas.
An under-painting. Sketchy, incomplete, but very good.

text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 22. 43 44
A clean, modern local service station. In the good part of town. The lights are on in the repair bays and the office.
Keith's in the repair bay working on a Jaguar. Drummer Girl's sitting on a work bench, tapping her sticks on various surfaces.
Jesus Christ! Drummer Girl looks up.
Two flies are having sex. It's amazing.
It happens. Keith goes back to work.
How's it feel to stand under an old Jaguar?
About the same as standing under an old Ford. Dirty and hot.
As she drums her way around the work bench, she hits Keit sketch book. She throws him a look back and opens the boo
You wanna stand under it?
She leafs through the book and the sketches of Amanda. Sh finds the tattered photo.
She looks at Keith.
He flips a tool in the box. (CONTINUED)
SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 22a.
She puts the photo back and closes the book
Are you calling out for food?
No. Keith returns to the underside of the car.
You can call if you want. (CONTINUED)
You have any money?
Yeah.
If I get hungrier, I'll call.
Don't you ever eat at home?
I don't like to eat alone.
Where's your mom?
Which way's the wind blowing? Drummer Girl leans back as she abruptly changes the subje
If you wanted to, you could blow every guy in this feeble town out of the water. From a female, popularity, sexual relationship standpoint. Keith looks at her. He doesn't understand what she means.
I'm not interested in blowing anybody out of the water.
Yeah?
Yeah.
So what's the deal with Amanda Jones? Keith pauses in his work. She's hit something. He con- tinues.
(looks down) I know you're thinking about her. (CONTINUED)
SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 24.
Wrong.

We've been friends too long to bullshit each other. I know when something's going on inside you. And I know Amanda Jones is on your mind. (looks up) You've always been on your own. I like you because you don't follow everybody. You're not sheep. You don't sell your soul to belong. And it's scary to me that you might change that.
Nothing's changing.
Look me in the eye and tell me you don't think about Amanda Jones. Keith turns to her.
So what if I do? What do you care?
Oh, come on. You're better than her. She's a major part of everything you don't believe in.
She's not that much different.
Yeah? Who's been lying to you? She's worse than different. She crossed town to belong to the lowest of the low. If that's the kind of person who inspires you, you've got a morality problem.
You sound a little jealous. Exactly. Drummer Girl is stunned that he nailed her feel- ings and is obliged to deny. (CONTINUED)
SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 25. 44 45 46
Of what? Her? Yeah, right.
You're afraid that, if I went out with Amanda, we couldn't be friends.

That would be entirely my choice and I'm not worried about it because, regardless of what I say, you're too internal to open up and ask her out, so why don't we change the subject? A BELL RINGS in the station. Keith flips his wrench into the tool box.
You brought it up.

Yeah. And I brought it up because I care about you. She doesn't. She has one thing on her mind and you don't make enough of it to matter to her. I rest my case. Keith wipes his hands on his jeans and exits the station.
Speak of the she-devil.
The black Corvette's parked at the pumps. Hardy and Amanda. Keith walks out of the repair bay.
He slows as he recognizes Amanda.
Hardy sees Keith. Amanda looks around at him. Hardy BLOWS the HORN and holds it several long beats.
He isn't amused. A hard, cold look passes over his face.
He walks around the front of the Corvette. (CONTINUED)

Twenty dollars, super unleaded. (pause, smile) Check the oil. Hardy reaches under the dash and pops the hood. Keith steps back to the pump and removes the hose. He uncaps the tank and shoves the hose nozzle in.
Be nice, or I'll make you check the tires. Keith sighs with disgust. He looks at Amanda. She avoids him.
So, this is what you do for a living, huh? Keith looks at him. Says nothing. He walks to the front of the car. He opens the hood.
You want to cut the engine?
My pleasure. He turns off the engine. Keith leans into the engine ca- vity and looks for the dipstick. He finds it and yanks it out. The HORN BLOWS.
Sorry about that. My hand slipped. Keith shakes his head at the cheap trick.
Amanda isn't amused by Hardy's cruelty.
Why don't you cut it out?
Why don't you mind your own business?
Drummer Girl slides down off the bench and walks to the door. She looks out. (CONTINUED)
Keith's checking the oil. Hardy and Amanda are talking. Keith slams the hood shut and walks back to the pump.
Keen interest in the situation.
Keith's watching the pump meter.
You like looking at my girlfriend, huh? Keith glares at him. Amanda gives Hardy ice.
(to Amanda) What? He likes looking at you.
Shut-up, Hardy. Keith removes the nozzle from the tank. Amanda shoots a look at him. He puts the hose back and looks at Amanda. A serious look. A look that preserves what's left of his dignity.
I'd recommend you keep your eyes and your mind off my property. He starts the engine. Keith smiles. He's not frightened. Hardy holds a twenty dollar bill between his index and middle finger.

Here's ten for the gas, ten for the look. Keith looks at the bill. Pulls it out of Hardy's hand. Keith smiles. Hardy slams the car in gear and screams out of the station. Keith watches him go. He folds the twenty and puts it in his shirt pocket. He reaches behind his back and pulls Hardy's dipstick out. He tosses it in the trash barrel. He walks back to the repair bay.
It reads, $8.00. Keith's only given him ten dollars worth of gas.  50 51 52 53 54 28.
Drummer Girl's seen everything. She'd like to kill Hardy. And possibly Amanda. Keith walks in.

Keith? I watched that. It was sick. If that isn't the raw, bleeding truth about Amanda Jones, I don't know what is. If you think that's interesting, you better pack it in. He picks up his tool and goes back to work under the Jagu Drummer Girl watches him. She turns up the RADIO and sits back on the bench.
Girls' gym. Tennis. A BELL RINGS. An INSTRUCTOR blows a whistle and waves the girls in.

Hardy's car pulls up fast and stops. Amanda gets out. She's wearing a gym uniform. She reaches into the car and grabs a tennis racket. She hurries up the steps onto the courts. Hardy pulls away. Amanda's class is heading back to school. She hurries to join them, hoping to avoid de- tection. She rushes into the crowd exiting the courts and quickly adjusts to their gait.
Keith and half a dozen other downtown boys are sitting on the bleachers. They've spent their gym period watching girls' gym. Keith sits up as he sees Amanda join her clas
FROM ABOVE, an Instructor cuts across the courts and call to Amanda.
Amanda Jones? Amanda slows and stops. She knows she's caught. She curses under her breath.
He leans over the side to watch and listen.
The Instructor catches up to Amanda. (CONTINUED)
Excusing yourself from class to leave the grounds with the boy with the hot car buys you two weeks of morning detention.
I was just talking to him.
If all you wanted was talk, you could have gotten it without leaving school.
What're you saying, Mrs. Albright?
Nothing that hasn't been said before. Amanda holds her look on the Instructor.
Get inside. Amanda turns angrily and heads for the school.
He's seen and heard the moment. A smile spreads across his face as an idea streaks through his brain.
A hand grabs it, pulls. The ALARM GOES OFF.
